title: Tropical disturbance will bring squally , wet weather to South Florida this weekend
message:
MIAMI - The CBS Miami NEXT Weather team continues to track the tropical disturbance in the Caribbean.
It has issued a Next Alert for Saturday as the moisture associated with this wave will produce rounds of heavy rain and the potential for flooding this weekend across South Florida.
Regardless of development, the biggest concern for South Florida will be the potential for rounds of heavy downpours and localized flooding.
There is a moderate threat of excessive rainfall in South Florida.
Some showers and a few storms moved across parts of South Florida during the morning.

title: Invest 97L continues path toward Florida . Here what to know
message:
ORLANDO, Fla. – A tropical wave continues on its path toward Florida, bringing the threat of heavy rain.
Invest 97L was designated as Potential Tropical Cyclone Four, which is over eastern Cuba as of Friday morning.
The latest tropical models differ a bit on where the system will be by Sunday and its intensity.
No matter what, Central Florida can expect tropical downpours to start entering the area by Saturday with the highest chances by Sunday through Tuesday.
Ron DeSantis declared a state of emergency for 54 Florida counties due to the possibility of flooding from the system.

title: Invest - 97L is continuing to move towards the Gulf .
message:
We’re set to spend another day in the 90′s, with “feels like temperatures” in the triple digits.
It’s highly likely that flash flooding could occur with these tropical downpours, but that’s all dependent on where this system ends up tracking.
According to the National Hurricane Center, once this system is over water, conditions for development are MUCH more favorable.
This system has the potential to become a Tropical Depression into this weekend.
Things can, and will change, and we will keep you updated on air and online.

It remains a tropical wave today as it moves across the Greater Antilles, namely eastern Cuba, likely on its way to the Gulf of Mexico.
It could still impact Florida, at minimum with rain, but still possibly as a tropical storm should it finally gain strength in the Gulf.

Such anecdotes pepper this accessible, concise history of earthquakes, which is exceptional in that it comes from an Indian vantage.
Only in the decade that men landed on the moon did earth scientists conclusively establish the theory explaining these links.
Plate tectonics, as this theory is called, also explains the formation of continents, volcanic activity, tsunamis and the intensity and timing of earthquakes.

title: Hurricane center says tropical storm watches , warnings possible for Florida today
message:
Tropical storm watches or warnings may be issued for parts of Florida on Friday, Aug. 2, as firing cloud tops and thunderstorms consolidate near the Florida Straits in a ripening system that could soon earn the name Debby.
If a tropical storm forms with sustained wind speeds of 39 mph or higher, it would be named Debby.
The National Hurricane Center says a tropical wave over the Greater Antilles has an 80% chance of development over the next seven days.
The NHC won't issue forecasts for intensity until a tropical depression forms, but some hurricane experts said models are bullish that a tropical storm or hurricane may form.
This article originally appeared on Palm Beach Post: Hurricane center increases chances Debby will form near Florida

title: Gov . DeSantis Declares State Of Emergency In Florida As Dangerous Storm Looms Over
message:
The NHC stated that while development is unlikely over the next few days as the system moves west-northwestward over portions of the Greater Antilles, conditions are expected to become more conducive for development afterward.
A tropical depression could form this weekend or early next week over the eastern Gulf of Mexico or far southwestern Atlantic Ocean, including near Florida.

title: Tracking the Tropics : Invest 97 timeline and what has changed with the forecast
message:
We woke up Friday morning to little change with the tropical wave located over eastern Cuba.
The wave called Invest 97L is causing 25 mph winds over the southeastern Bahamas as it tracks westward across Cuba on Friday.
The National Hurricane Center gives it a 60% chance of developing in the next 48 hours and 90% over the next seven days.
Later this evening NOAA will fly a P-3 to collect radar data near Andros Island to improve tonight’s forecast model accuracy.
The window to intensify will be short since it will spend much of its time over Cuba and Florida.

title: SHAREHOLDER ALERT : Pomerantz Law Firm Investigates Claims On Behalf of Investors of CenterPoint Energy , Inc .
message:
NEW YORK, Aug. 1, 2024 /PRNewswire/ -- Pomerantz LLP is investigating claims on behalf of investors of CenterPoint Energy, Inc. ("CenterPoint" or the "Company") (NYSE: CNP).
The investigation concerns whether CenterPoint and certain of its officers and/or directors have engaged in securities fraud or other unlawful business practices.
At a press conference on July 14, 2024, Texas Governor Greg Abbott said that he was demanding an investigation into CenterPoint's response to Hurricane Beryl.
Founded by the late Abraham L. Pomerantz, known as the dean of the class action bar, Pomerantz pioneered the field of securities class actions.

title: Forecasters Warn Invest97 Could Develop into Tropical Storm
message:
(Miami, FL) -- The National Hurricane Center is keeping an eye on a storm system in the Atlantic that could develop into Tropical Storm Debby.
Forecasters say the system is currently producing thunderstorms over Puerto Rico and the Virgin Islands, and could threaten the U.S. mainland as early as this weekend.
Accuweather says the storm is headed for the eastern Gulf Coast, and is warning coastal residents from Florida to Louisiana to be ready.
Tropical storm watches or warnings could be required for portions of Florida later today.
The wave is expected to move near or over Cuba throughout the day and then emerge over the Straits of Florida tonight or Saturday.

title: South Florida could get drenched as tropical wave passes on its way to the Gulf of Mexico
message:
South Florida could get drenched as tropical wave passes on its way to the Gulf of MexicoSouth Florida and the Florida Keys are in for a rainy weekend as a disorganized tropical wave — on the verge of strengthening into a tropical depression — is set to pass south of the state on Saturday.
Florida could see tropical storm watches or warnings later Friday in advance of the system, which would be named Debby.
South Florida wasn’t included.
The National Hurricane Center has been tracking the tropical wave for a week and steadily upping its chances of getting its act together.
The tropical wave crossing Cuba is likely to strengthen into a tropical depression sometime over the weekend.

Its focus currently is on the restoration of coral reefs in east Portland.
Jamaica is still reeling from the effects of Hurricane Beryl, which passed over the island on July 3.
“Coral reefs are one of our major barriers to storm surges and hurricanes.
The CoralCarib project will see both Nature Conservancy and the Alligator Head Foundation working to educate Jamaicans on preservation and restoration activities.

title: Invest 97L forecast : Tropical disturbance tracking towards Gulf of Mexico , near Florida
message:
The National Hurricane Center (NHC) said a tropical disturbance over Hispaniola, known as Invest 97L, is highly likely to develop further over the next seven days and possibly become a tropical depression as early as this weekend.
As it moves toward the Gulf of Mexico, it's expected to enter an environment more favorable for further development.
The NHC said it could become a tropical depression this weekend or early next week over the Gulf of Mexico, not far from Florida.
The tropical wave is getting more organized now and is starting to produce some big thunderstorms, as seen from satellite.
For Central Florida (FOX 35 and 51 counties), this system is likely to impact the area from Sunday to Monday.

message:

HEAT WAVE #1...Here’s a breakdown of our June heat wave: Monday (June 17th) the high for Hartford Area was 90... not record-breaking, but the 1st day of the heat wave.
The high in Bridgeport was 72°, setting a record for March 15th; previously, the record high was 65° from 1990.
When it comes to temperature, it was the 9th warmest with an average temperature of 53.7° (4.2° above normal).
From June 28th through August 12th, every day featured a high temperature at or above 80 in the Hartford Area.

title: SVG on the brink of food insecurity - Agriculture Minister
message:
NewsAs the impact from Hurricane Beryl continues to be assessed, preliminary damage assessments paint a grim picture for the agriculture sector in St Vincent and the Grenadines (SVG).
Fisheries and agriculture have taken a hard hit with Minister Saboto Caesar describing the situation by saying that the country is now “on the brink of food insecurity”.
Minister Caesar explained that while the full damage assessment is yet to be completed, preliminary estimates show that the lobster and conch fishery were “basically destroyed”, while seamoss production was “totally gone”.
Hurricane Beryl also resulted in the loss of between 90 to 95 percent of banana and plantain trees.
I want for us to take careful note that we are on the brink of food insecurity.”Caesar lamented the repeated blows SVG has suffered due to climate events over the last decade, and he noted that the situation has worsened in recent years.

title: Cape Coral handyman gets months in jail after changing plea in Hurricane Ian fraud case
message:
Cape Coral handyman gets months in jail after changing plea in Hurricane Ian fraud caseThe city of Cape Coral showed major signs of damage after strong winds and flood waters as a result of Hurricane Ian impacted areas of the city on Thursday September 29, 2022.
This week, Aug. 1, 2024, a handyman who attempted to commit fraud in collecting money from residents to repair homes was sentenced to 9 months in jail.
A Cape Coral handyman accused of failing to complete work he was paid for after Hurricane Ian learned his fate this week after he changed his plea last month.
Hurricane Ian struck Southwest Florida as a Category 5 storm on Sept. 28, 2022, particularly devastating Cape Coral, Fort Myers Beach and Sanibel and Pine islands.
This article originally appeared on Naples Daily News: Cape Coral handyman sentenced to jail for Hurricane Ian fraud

title: High chance of a tropical system targeting Florida this weekend
message:
Forecast Centre The Weather Network A tropical disturbance has a high chance of developing into a storm by this weekend as it approaches FloridaFlorida is on alert as a tropical disturbance gathering steam over the northern Caribbean takes aim at the state this weekend.
Forecasters give the disturbance a 70 percent (high) chance of developing into a tropical depression or a tropical storm over the next couple of days.
Vacationers are advised to keep a close watch on forecasts over the coming days as this system draws closer to the Sunshine State.
Environmental conditions around the disturbance will gradually become favourable for tropical development as it moves west-northwest toward Florida this weekend.
MUST SEE: Tropical systems don’t need a name to trigger devastating floodsVery warm water temperatures, sufficient humidity, and calmer winds should allow the disturbance to develop into a tropical depression or tropical storm by the end of the weekend.

title: At least 30 dead after Typhoon Gaemi cut off towns in China Hunan province - Boston News , Weather , Sports
message:
Hong Kong (CNN) — Heavy rains and floods from Typhoon Gaemi caused at least 30 deaths and left 35 people missing across eight towns in the southern Chinese province of Hunan, state-run news agency Xinhua reported on Thursday, citing local authorities.
On Thursday, rescue teams reached eight towns that had been cut off from the outside world since last Sunday, due to destroyed infrastructure and power grids.
Typhoon Gaemi initially made landfall in China on the evening of Thursday July 25, with winds approaching 110 kph (70 mph).
The storm previously caused torrential flooding in Taiwan, with rainfall in five townships totaling over 1,285mm (50 inches).
Typhoon Gaemi was deflected off its forecasted track by Taiwan’s mountainous terrain and spent more than six hours offshore, making a loop near the Hualien coastline instead of making landfall on the evening of Wednesday, July 24.

title: At least 30 dead after Typhoon Gaemi cut off towns in China Hunan province
message:
By Shawn Deng, Hassan Tayir and Duarte Mendonca, CNNHong Kong (CNN) — Heavy rains and floods from Typhoon Gaemi caused at least 30 deaths and left 35 people missing across eight towns in the southern Chinese province of Hunan, state-run news agency Xinhua reported on Thursday, citing local authorities.
On Thursday, rescue teams reached eight towns that had been cut off from the outside world since last Sunday, due to destroyed infrastructure and power grids.
Typhoon Gaemi initially made landfall in China on the evening of Thursday July 25, with winds approaching 110 kph (70 mph).
The storm previously caused torrential flooding in Taiwan, with rainfall in five townships totaling over 1,285mm (50 inches).
Typhoon Gaemi was deflected off its forecasted track by Taiwan’s mountainous terrain and spent more than six hours offshore, making a loop near the Hualien coastline instead of making landfall on the evening of Wednesday, July 24.

title: Govt must provide additional disaster management funds to states without discrimination : Mallikarjun Kharge
message: OTHERSOTHERSassociated byco-presented byFollow us on:My AccountororHello, LoginAllGovt must provide additional disaster management funds to states without discrimination: Mallikarjun Kharge

title: Severe thunderstorms and flooding drive natural disaster losses in the first half of 2024 – ICSF
message:
However, 2023 was affected by extremely high losses in connection with the severe earthquake in Turkey and Syria.
Notably, the share of claims for “non-peak perils” – which include severe thunderstorms, flooding and forest fires – was once again high: 68% of total losses and 76% of insured losses were caused by these natural disasters.
The costliest natural disaster in the first half of the year was an earthquake in Japan on New Year’s Day.
Estimated total losses amounted to some US$ 10bn, including insured losses of roughly US$ 2bn.
One year earlier, overall losses for the first half-year were roughly US$ 52bn, including insured losses of US$ 40bn.

title: Govt must provide additional disaster management funds to states without discrimination : Kharge
message:
Amid natural calamities in various parts of the country, Congress president Mallikarjun Kharge on Friday demanded that the Modi government should immediately provide additional disaster management funds to states without any discrimination.
He made the remarks while condoling the loss of lives due to cloudburst and heavy rainfall in Uttarakhand.
"The country is grappling with climate change, where floods, heavy rainfall, cloudburst and drought-like emergent situations have occurred in many states.
"We will also have to improve our disaster management.
To deal with these natural calamities occurring year after year, the Modi government should immediately provide additional disaster management funds to the states without any discrimination, the Congress chief asserted.

title: Plastic pollution , seawater flooding can amplify threats to coastal plant species : Study
message:
The study was led by experts in plastic pollution and plant biology from the University of Plymouth's School of Biological and Marine Sciences and the International Marine Litter Research Unit.
The study, published in Environmental Contamination, is one of the first to investigate the impact of saltwater floods and microplastic contamination on coastal plants.
It showed that both stressors had some effects on the species tested, with microplastics impacting the plants' reproduction while flooding caused greater tissue death.
Dr Winnie Courtene-Jones, the study's lead author, said, "This research highlights the potential for microplastics, composed of conventional and biodegradable plastic, to detrimentally affect plant functioning.
Moreso, it indicates that the effect of microplastics can be magnified by other environmental factors such as rising sea levels and coastal flooding.

title: Tropical Threat in Gulf Elevated - What Louisiana Can Expect
message:
The National Hurricane Center is describing an area of disturbed weather near the island of Hispaniola as a "well-defined tropical wave".
The graphic above indicates that we are about to enter the peak of the Atlantic Tropical Season.
And while forecasters have predicted a very busy tropical season so far we've only had three named storms.
The probability of a tropical depression or tropical storm forming today or Saturday is about 50%.
The next official update from the National Hurricane Center will come at 0700 CDT or sooner should conditions warrant.

title: Heavy downpours batter the united kingdom as temperatures soar to 30C
message:
A yellow warning for thunderstorms was issued by the forecaster that covered the majority of the UK on Thursday as temperatures soared to highs of 30C.
Drivers faced road closures and there were disruptions to public transport, power cuts and flooding.
Benson Lock in Oxfordshire recorded 30mm of rainfall in an hour while Wisley, Surrey, enjoyed the highest temperature of the day of 30.2C.
Met Office meteorologist Simon Partridge said: “There’s been very humid air which is why it’s felt so close and muggy as well.
“The same air has been over northern France for the last day or two as well – so those heavy thundery showers that they had during the triathlon yesterday morning.

title: Minor Earthquake Felt in Parts of New York State
message:

title: Tropical development likely in the Gulf this weekend
message:
TAMPA, Fla. — A strong tropical wave (Invest 97L) moves over Cuba today and then into the Gulf of Mexico this weekend.
If it becomes a tropical storm, the name would be Debby.
Right now, all the computer guidance shows the intensity as a tropical depression or tropical storm.
It is important to remember, with a disorganized tropical depression or tropical storm, the exact center doesn’t matter as much.
Be sure to check back often as development is likely pretty close to the west coast of Florida as early as Sunday morning.

If it becomes a tropical storm, the name would be Debby.
Right now, all the computer guidance shows the intensity as a tropical depression or tropical storm.
It is important to remember, with a disorganized tropical depression or tropical storm, the exact center doesn’t matter as much.
Be sure to check back often as development is likely pretty close to the west coast of Florida as early as Sunday morning.

title: Heavy downpours batter the united kingdom as temperatures soar to 30C
message:
A yellow warning for thunderstorms was issued by the forecaster that covered the majority of the UK on Thursday as temperatures soared to highs of 30C.
Drivers faced road closures and there were disruptions to public transport, power cuts and flooding.
Benson Lock in Oxfordshire recorded 30mm of rainfall in an hour while Wisley, Surrey, enjoyed the highest temperature of the day of 30.2C.
Met Office meteorologist Simon Partridge said: “There’s been very humid air which is why it’s felt so close and muggy as well.
“The same air has been over northern France for the last day or two as well – so those heavy thundery showers that they had during the triathlon yesterday morning.

title: Latest Projected Path of Tropical System Shifts Closer to Texas
message:
Invest 97LThat's the name that the National Hurricane Center has given to a tropical system that continues to push west-northwestward across Puerto Rico.
National Hurricane Center National Hurricane Center loading...
Every weather model I have seen turns this tropical system northward into the U.S. before reaching New Orleans.
National Hurricane Center/Canva National Hurricane Center/Canva loading...
Never Say NeverEven though there is a very low possibility of this tropical system adjusting its track to Texas, it would be a good idea to monitor the latest updates, just in case.

title: Danger and despair amid darkness in Salt River
message:
Residents of Salt River in Clarendon say they're living like prisoners in their own homes, forced to retreat indoors by 7 p.m. daily due to safety concerns.
Criminals aren't afraid to strike after dark, so by 7 p.m., or even 6 p.m., when it starts getting dark, everyone has to lock up.
Salt River Road was on the schedule for restoration yesterday.
Another long-time Salt River resident noted that the community was peaceful until Hurricane Beryl hit.
Sitting on the sidewalk with friends, a chef lamented having to hang up his apron due to the power outage.

title: For the record , I dont keep very good records
message:
She’d record the first frost and make sure her mountains of pumpkins were doing well.
!”If anyone asked, she could quickly go back to her records and report on any interesting phenomenon that struck the farm.
ADVERTISEMENTI myself am a reporter who records people’s words and actions for much of my living, and yet, I keep basically no records of the day-to-day weather we experience at home.
I don’t have to tell you why good recordkeeping matters, but I’m going to anyway.
Read more from Michael Johnson here:Here’s a great example of how good intentions can fail without some simple recordkeeping.

title: A simple guide to understanding inflation
message:
In simple terms, inflation refers to an increase in the price of goods and services over a period of time.
Inflation can happen when the demand for products or services exceeds the supply.
The Reserve Bank of India (RBI), the central agency, monitors the inflation rate in India.
Usually, when the inflation rate increases, the central bank increases the key lending rate on loans and deposits, discouraging consumers as well as businesses from taking out a loan.
For fixing the interest rates to tackle inflation, the RBI constituted a six-member monitory policy committee (MPC) headed by Governor Shaktikanta Das.

title: Status of Union Island Gecko unknown after Hurricane Beryl
message:
NewsThe Forestry Department is preparing to conduct an assessment following the passage of Hurricane Beryl to determine the status of endemic species in the Southern Grenadines, particularly the Union Island Gecko.
Providence said the team has to assess the status of the gecko population as there was significant damage on the forested areas on Union Island.
The Union Island Gecko (Gonatodes daudini) is an endemic species found in the Chatham Bay forest area and is considered endangered due to the high demand from the illegal international pet trade.
“When you look at the forest on Union Island, particularly the Chatham Bay forest area, we saw that there was total defoliation, just sticks standing.
He expressed confidence that the forested areas will rebound over time as was the case in Dominica when they were hit by a category five hurricane.

title: TIMING , IMPACTS : Here what to expect in Central Florida with tropical wave
message:
ORLANDO, Fla. – A high chance for further development is expected Friday morning with a tropical wave over Cuba.
TIMING:Local model runs show tropical rain bands feeding into Central Florida by Saturday afternoon across southern counties, with northern counties seeing a little less.
FLORIDA TROPICAL TIMELINEThe surge of moisture is expected to arrive by Sunday with bands of squally gusty downpours streaming in starting Sunday morning and heavier rain by the afternoon.
RAIN MODEL SUNDAYLOCAL IMPACTS:Regardless of exact track and intensity, Central Florida should prepare for a tropical system to be nearby between Sunday and Tuesday with rainfall being the biggest concern.
EURO FORECAST RAIN TOTALSThe News 6 Pinpoint Weather Team will continue to update the local timeline and impacts with this tropical system as the forecast models come into better agreement.

title: Invest 97L tracker : Forecast path , spaghetti models , timeline , watches and warnings
message:
Stream FOX 35 NewsThe National Hurricane Center has named a tropical disturbance in the Atlantic with a high chance of further development over the next seven days.
Invest 97L could possibly become a tropical depression or storm as early as this weekend.
It's still too early to tell exactly where this tropical wave will end up, whether it will become Tropical Storm Debby, and whether it will stay in the Gulf of Mexico or if it will make landfall over Florida – and where.
RELATED HEADLINES:Below are the latest models that track the storm's possible development, path, timeline, and impacts.

title: NY weather stays hot and stormy through weekend ; track radar here – NBC New York
message:
Nearly every day has brought at least a few showers or storms, and we are going to increase the storm activity into the weekend.
Some of those storms could be strong to severe, capable of producing some locally heavy rainfall.
Extreme heat in and around the tri-state area will contribute to the instability, too.
Friday’s storms will be strongest from the New York City area to the west and south.
The main threats from Friday’s and the weekend’s storms will be isolated flooding where downpours are the heaviest and isolated damaging straight line wind gusts.

title: Hot temps , drought have meteorologists worried about the rest of Idaho wildfire season
message:
The 2024 wildfire season is barely at the halfway mark, yet an especially dry, hot, and active summer has already resulted in 2024 wildfires burning over 4 million acres nationwide.
The Northwest wildfire season typically peaks in early July, according to the National Weather Service, and lasts until early September.
Idaho’s 2024 wildfire season began in mid-July when smoke from two fires in northern California and eastern Oregon began blowing eastward.
As of Thursday morning, the Cow Valley fire was 99% contained and had burned 133,490 acres, according to federal wildfire tracker InciWeb.
Parker said this year’s wildfire season has started strongly because of drought and scorching temperatures.

title: Rain - related disasters have killed more than 200 in a deadly week across Asia
message:
Rain-related disasters have killed more than 250 in a deadly week across AsiaFILE - Rescuers use a dinghy boat to evacuate villagers trapped by floodwaters in Jingtang village, Zixing city, in southern China's Hunan province, on July 28, 2024.
(Chinatopix via AP, File)In India and China, torrential rains have killed more than 250 people in the past week.
Widespread flooding has been reported in North Korea near the border with China with no word on whether anyone died.
In North Korea, the rain flooded 4,100 houses, 3,000 hectares (7,400 acres) of farmland and many public buildings, roads and railways.
One city near North Korea asked people living below the third floor to move higher as the Yalu River rose.

title: Extreme flooding , rain kills 250 in India and China
message:
In India and China, torrential rains have killed more than 250 people in the past week.
Widespread flooding has been reported in North Korea near the border with China with no word on whether anyone died.
This time of year is monsoon and typhoon season in Asia, and climate change has intensified such storms.
In North Korea, the rain flooded 4,100 houses, 3,000 hectares (7,400 acres) of farmland and many public buildings, roads and railways.

title: Congressman Eric Sorensen visits Fulton County to survey damage from July storms
message:
FULTON COUNTY, Ill. (WMBD) — Congressmen Eric Sorensen (D-17) visited Fulton County Thursday evening to assess damage from the severe storms that swept through the area in mid-July.
Fulton County leaders, and Illinois Emergency Management Agency representatives sat down with the congressman to explain the damage and what problems they are facing.
Leaders said in order to get help from the Federal Emergency Management Agency, the area needs to meet certain benchmarks.
There needs to be $23.6 in uninsured damages, which Fulton County is having trouble meeting.
We’re never going to reach that benchmark.”Sorensen plans to take what he learned from the Fulton County leaders to Washington D.C. and work to change the process to receive federal help to assess storm damage.

title: Disturbance to enter the Gulf this weekend ; intense heat locally
message:
MOBILE, Ala. (WALA) - It will be an uncomfortable and at times dangerously hot day across the Gulf coast.
We’re used to hot weather, but don’t let the heat sneak up on you!
When someone is suffering from heat exhaustion or heat stroke they’ll often be confused and find it hard to care for themselves.
We are continuing to track an area of disturbed weather as it approaches the Gulf of Mexico.
It appears that it will move through the Eastern Gulf and then up the west coast of Florida.

title: South Korea says it is ready to offer flood damage relief to North Korea
message:
SEOUL - South Korea is ready to provide North Korea with relief supplies for damage caused by recent heavy rainfall, South Korea's Red Cross said on Aug 1, marking a rare outreach under the administration of President Yoon Suk-yeol to its neighbour.
North Korean leader Kim Jong Un personally inspected the flooded areas and expressed grave concern over the damage, state media said on July 29.
There is a possibility of "significant human casualties" in North Korea, a Unification Ministry official said on Aug 1.
South Korea's TV Chosun reported more than 1,100 people and as many as 1,500 people dead or missing, citing an unnamed government official.
More rain was forecast for Sinuiju on Aug 1 and early Aug 2, according to South Korea's weather agency.

title: Colorado wildfire updates : Alexander Mountain fire grows to 9 , 000 acres
message:
Colorado wildfire updates for Friday, Aug. 2, 2024One of the multiple fires burning along Colorado’s Front Range this week — the Quarry fire in Jefferson County, just west of Denver — is now being investigated as arson, law enforcement officials announced Friday morning.
The Quarry fire burning on more than 400 acres of land in Jefferson County is being investigated as arson, sheriff’s officials announced Friday.
Kevin Bost, division chief for the Jefferson County Sheriff’s Office’s criminal investigations division, said investigators are conducting an arson investigation.
The 1,553-acre Stone Canyon fire burning near Lyons in Boulder County was 30% contained Thursday night.
County officials confirmed Thursday that human remains were found in a burned structure in the 2600 block of Eagle Ridge Road.

title: Rain - related disasters have killed more than 200 in a deadly week across Asia – Winnipeg Free Press
message:
In India and China, torrential rains have killed more than 250 people in the past week.
Widespread flooding has been reported in North Korea near the border with China with no word on whether anyone died.
Heavy rains have triggered landslides and flooding, devastating crops, destroying homes and taking lives.
(AP Photo/Fareed Khan, File)In North Korea, the rain flooded 4,100 houses, 3,000 hectares (7,400 acres) of farmland and many public buildings, roads and railways.
One city near North Korea asked people living below the third floor to move higher as the Yalu River rose.

title: 27 dead as heavy rains , flash floods batter KP , Punjab
message:
The Provincial Disaster Management Authority (PDMA) has reported that torrential rains and flash floods in Khyber-Pakhtunkhwa (K-P) have claimed the lives of 24 individuals over the past three days.
The heavy rains and resulting accidents have affected various districts, including Kohat, Bajaur, Upper and Lower Chitral, Upper Dir, Upper and Lower Kohistan, Abbottabad, Haripur, Swat, Charsadda, Swabi, Mohmand, South Waziristan, and Hangu.
Rescue operations are underway in the affected areas, with district administrations and relief teams actively engaged in providing assistance.
Lahore’s rainfall led to significant flooding in areas such as Mall Road, Ferozepur Road, Model Town, Faisal Town, Lakshmi Chowk, and Anarkali.
Meanwhile, Chief Minister Punjab Maryam Nawaz Sharif has directed members of the provincial assembly (MPAs) to oversee the rainwater drainage operation.
